messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 61 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: A New Conjecture on Hardness of Low-Degree 2-CSP‚Äôs with Implications to Hardness of Densest ùëò-Subgraph and Other Problems

Paper Abstract: We propose a new conjecture on hardness of low-degree 222-CSP‚Äôs, and show that new hardness of approximation results for Densest kùëòk-Subgraph and several other problems, including a graph partitioning problem, and a variation of the Graph Crossing Number problem, follow from this conjecture. The conjecture can be viewed as occupying a middle ground between the dùëëd-to-111 conjecture, and hardness results for 222-CSP‚Äôs that can be obtained via standard techniques, such as Parallel Repetition combined with standard 222-prover protocols for the 3SAT problem. We hope that this work will motivate further exploration of hardness of 222-CSP‚Äôs in the regimes arising from the conjecture. We believe that a positive resolution of the conjecture will provide a good starting point for further hardness of approximation proofs. Another contribution of our work is proving that the problems that we consider are roughly equivalent from the approximation perspective. Some of these problems arose in previous work, from which it appeared that they may be related to each other. We formalize this relationship in this work.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 61 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 61"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Inapproximabilty of densest k-subgraph from average case hardness",
        "Subexponential algorithms for unique games and related problems",
        "Crossing-free subgraphs",
        "On sparse spanners of weighted graphs",
        "Inapproximability results for sparsest cut, optimal linear arrangement, and precedence constrained scheduling",
        "Expander flows, geometric embeddings and graph partitioning",
        "Approximating nash equilibria and dense bipartite subgraphs via an approximate version of caratheodory‚Äôs theorem",
        "Detecting high log-densities: an O(n1/41/4{}^{\\mbox{1/4}}) approximation for densest k-subgraph",
        "Polynomial integrality gaps for strong sdp relaxations of densest k-subgraph",
        "Memory on the number of values a function can take: when you swap the letters it contains",
        "Making the long code shorter",
        "Eth hardness for densest-k-subgraph with perfect completeness",
        "Small-set expansion in shortcode graph and the 2-to-2 conjecture",
        "Extremal graph theory",
        "Hardness of approximation for crossing number",
        "The hardness and approximation of the densest k-subgraph problem in parameterized metric graphs",
        "The densest k-subhypergraph problem",
        "M√©moire sur les nombres premiers",
        "A tighter insertion-based approximation of the crossing number",
        "An algorithm for the graph crossing number problem",
        "Excluded grid theorem: Improved and simplified",
        "Almost polynomial hardness of node-disjoint paths in grids",
        "On graph crossing number and edge planarization",
        "Towards better approximation of graph crossing number",
        "Approximation algorithms for euler genus and related problems",
        "A subpolynomial approximation algorithm for graph crossing number in low-degree graphs",
        "On non-optimally expanding sets in Grassmann graphs",
        "Towards a proof of the 2-to-1 games conjecture?",
        "Concentration of measure for the analysis of randomized algorithms",
        "Improved approximations of crossings in graph drawings and vlsi layout areas",
        "Relations between average case complexity and approximation complexity",
        "Approximation algorithms for maximization problems arising in graph partitioning",
        "The dense k-subgraph problem",
        "On the densest k-subgraph problem",
        "The dense k subgraph problem",
        "Computing densest kùëòk-subgraph with structural parameters",
        "Some optimal inapproximability results",
        "On the power of unique 2-prover 1-round games",
        "Ruling out ptas for graph min-bisection, dense k-subgraph, and bipartite clique",
        "On the hardness of approximating the chromatic number",
        "Small set expansion in the Johnson graph",
        "On independent sets, 2-to-2 games, and Grassmann graphs",
        "Pseudorandom sets in Grassmann graph have near-perfect expansion",
        "On choosing a dense subgraph",
        "A two-prover one-round game with strong soundness",
        "Polylogarithmic approximation for minimum planarization (almost)",
        "Polylogarithmic approximation for euler genus on bounded degree graphs",
        "Complexity issues in VLSI: optimal layouts for the shuffle-exchange graph and other networks",
        "The parameterized complexity of the k-biclique problem",
        "Multicommodity max-flow min-cut theorems and their use in designing approximation algorithms",
        "A separator theorem for planar graphs",
        "Almost-polynomial ratio ETH-hardness of approximating densest k-subgraph",
        "Inapproximability of maximum biclique problems, minimum k-cut and densest at-least-k-subgraph from the small set expansion hypothesis",
        "Lectures on discrete geometry",
        "Applications of the crossing number",
        "Thirteen problems on crossing numbers",
        "Crossing numbers",
        "The graph crossing number and its variants: A survey",
        "On solving the densest k-subgraph problem on large graphs",
        "Subexponential algorithms for d-to-1 two-prover games and for certifying almost perfect expansion",
        "A note of welcome"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 61 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in A New Conjecture on Hardness of Low-Degree 2-CSP‚Äôs with Implications to Hardness of Densest ùëò-Subgraph and Other Problems, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
